newsitem.title: GERMANY: Lively German Bunds keen to tackle 101.00 barrier.
newsitem.headline: Lively German Bunds keen to tackle 101.00 barrier.

text.p: German June Bund futures were in the mood for another stab at 101.00 resistance on Wednesday but traders said the next hurdle at 101.13 was likely to remain only a hope for now.
After gapping higher at the open, the contract will be well supported on the downside with a hole stretching from 100.79 down to 100.68 on daily price charts.
By 0723 GMT, the June DTB contract was 16 basis points higher at 100.82, just off its earlier high on 100.89. The cash 10-year Bund was at 101.13 for a yield of 5.834 percent.

"The market is looking pretty healthy this morning, said one futures trader based in London. "We should take a look at the 101.00 area, but the next resistance at 101.13 still looks a bit too far for now."
Resistance at 101.13 is given by a 50 percent Fibonacci retracement of the decline from 103.20 to 99.06.

In the cash market, traders said that after initial discomfort, the first tranche of the new 10-year Federal bond due August 2007 went down well on Tuesday -- boding well for the second tranche, expected to be around 10 billion marks, which is due to be sold at auction this session.
Traders said that the Federal Bond Consortium of banks through which the first 5.0 billion mark tranche was issued on Tuesday had got the new paper priced at around 100.575.
Initial quotes early on Wednesday had the 10-year trading at 100.83 for a yield of 5.882, suggesting the paper had been well absorbed and demand remained good.

Elsewhere, analysts said the market was awaiting European Commission forecasts for 1997/8 economic and budgetary performance, due at 0900 GMT. Forecasts for Germany were expected to show it able to reach the 3.0 percent deficit/GDP ratio laid down by Maastricht for the single currency.

On spreads, the 10-year yield gap between Bunds and T-notes had slimmed to 112 basis points by 0748 GMT from 113 at Tuesday's close. But the German market continued to outperform its Italian counterpart, pushing the 10-year spread out to 180 basis points from 178 late on Tuesday.
